metadata.case_name: Workmen of Dimakuchi Tea Estate represented by Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha v. Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate

facts.text: Appellants are workmen of Dimakuchi tea estate represented by Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha, Dibrugarh. Respondent is management of Dimakuchi tea estate, district Darrang, Assam.
Dr. K. Banerjee appointed assistant medical officer of Dimakuchi tea estate with effect from November 1, 1950, subject to satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

Appointment letter stated: While on probation, suitability for permanent employment considered; if unsuitable, seven days' notice terminating appointment; if misconduct, instant dismissal; if suitable at end, confirmed.
In February 1951, Dr. Banerjee given increment of Rs. 5 per mensem.
On April 21, 1951, manager Mr. Booth terminated Dr. Banerjee's services effective April 22, 1951, with one month's salary in lieu of notice. No reasons given initially.
Dr. Banerjee inquired reasons; reply: reasons on medical side known to Dr. Cox; main reason deceitful addition of figures to medical indent after signed by Dr. Cox.

Manager later stated discharge on ground of incompetence in medical duties; Dr. Cox found incompetent, insufficient knowledge of microscopical/lab work; faulty quinine injection to Mr. Peacock causing severe illness nearly paralysis.
Cause espoused by Mangaldai Circle of Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha; secretary wrote to manager inquiring reasons.
Conciliation proceedings held unsuccessfully over termination.
Referred to Tripartite Appellate Board (Labour Commissioner Assam, reps of Tea Assoc and Sangha); recommended reinstatement from date of discharge.
Respondent offered 28 months salary/allowances in lieu of reinstatement; appellants did not agree.
Dr. Banerjee received Rs. 306-1-0 on May 22, 1951 and left tea garden.

Government of Assam notification December 23, 1953 referred dispute to Tribunal (Shri U. K. Gohain) under s.10(1)(c): Whether management justified in dismissing Dr. K. P. Banerjee, AMO? If not, entitled to reinstatement or other relief?
Tribunal held Dr. Banerjee not a workman; no industrial dispute; no jurisdiction.
Appeal to Labour Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta (Appeal No. Cal. 220 of 1954); affirmed, dispute not between employers and workmen.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court March 14, 1956, limited to whether dispute re non-workman falls within s.2(k).

legal_issues.text: Whether a dispute in relation to termination of service of Dr. K. P. Banerjee, who is not a workman within the meaning of the Act, falls within the scope of the definition of 'industrial dispute' in s.2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: Expression 'of any person' in third part of s.2(k) is wide; not equated to 'any workman'; dispute between employer and workmen connected with non-employment of Dr. Banerjee (not workman) is industrial dispute.

Limitations on 'any person': real/substantial dispute where relief possible; relates to same establishment; person is employee discharged/in service/candidate; workmen have nexus via personal/general labour interest.

respondent_arguments.text: Dr. Banerjee not workman; dispute not between employers and workmen; no industrial dispute; Tribunal no jurisdiction.
'Any person' limited to persons with community of interest to workmen; Dr. Banerjee supervisory/medical staff, no such interest.

court_reasoning.text: S.2(k) analysed into three parts: dispute/difference; between employers/employers, employers/workmen, workmen/workmen; connected with employment/non-employment/terms/conditions of labour of any person.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Any person' cannot mean anybody; limited by context/scheme of Act to person in whose employment etc. parties (workmen) have direct/substantial interest/community of interest.

court_reasoning.text: Act for workmen (manual/clerical); distinguishes from supervisory; objects: amity, settlement disputes between specified parties, prevent strikes/lockouts, etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Absurd if workmen dispute DM/Judge employment; no community interest.

court_reasoning.text: Dr. Banerjee not workman; medical staff different category; appellants no direct/substantial interest in his non-employment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if union member, no industrial dispute.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J. (separate): Words 'any person' ordinary meaning includes non-workmen; no valid restriction to 'workman class'; scheme does not limit; interest of workmen in dispute assumed real.

holdings.text: Dispute regarding non-employment of person not workman is industrial dispute only if workmen as class have direct/substantial interest/community of interest therein.
Dr. Banerjee dispute not industrial dispute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents_cited.relevance: Absurd results if 'any person' unlimited; community of interest test.

precedents_cited.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Re non-employment of discharged workmen; illustrations not determinative here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Newspapers Ltd. v. State Industrial Tribunal, U.P.
Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S.N. Modak

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of industrial dispute and workman; scheme for adjudication, binding nature of awards.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed holding that the dispute over termination of Dr. K.P. Banerjee, not being a workman, and lacking community of interest with workmen, is not an industrial dispute under s.2(k). No order as to costs.

key_quotes.text: 'Any person' in s.2(k) means a person in whose employment, non-employment etc. the workmen as a class have a direct or substantial interest-with whom they have a community of interest.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of 'industrial dispute'

key_quotes.text: The Act is primarily meant for regulating the relations of employers and workmen-past, present and future. It draws a distinction between workmen as such and the managerial or supervisory staff.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains scheme distinguishing workmen from others
